trans-unit.source: Supports cookieless devices by appending appropriate authentication information to the appropriate URLs.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This helper class is designed to assist with writing authenticated mobile Web sites.

The class objects provide mobile device-compatible versions of the ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.Security.FormsAuthentication> class methods, <xref:System.Web.Mobile.MobileFormsAuthentication.RedirectFromLoginPage%2A> and <xref:System.Web.Mobile.MobileFormsAuthentication.SignOut%2A>.
For more information on securing your Web application, see [Basic Security Practices for Web Applications](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Redirects an authenticated user to the originally requested URL after logging in.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The methods create an encrypted string from the authentication cookie and append it to the redirecting URL of the originating request.
A client-side redirect is then issued for that URL.

This can be used to work around the limitations of certain mobile devices that either do not support cookies, or support cookies that are too small for storing authentication information in a secure manner.
Name of the user for cookie authentication purposes.
This does not need to map to an account name and is used by URL Authorization.
Specifies whether or not a durable cookie (one that is session based or outlasts the session) must be issued.
Redirects an authenticated user to the originally requested URL after logging in.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The methods create an encrypted string from the authentication cookie and append it to the redirecting URL of the originating request.
A client-side redirect is then issued for that URL.

This can be used to work around the limitations of certain mobile devices that either do not support cookies, or support cookies that are too small for storing authentication information in a secure manner.
Name of the user for cookie authentication purposes.
This does not need to map to an account name and is used by URL Authorization.
Specifies whether or not a durable cookie (one that is session based or outlasts the session) must be issued.
Returns the configured cookie path used for the current application.

Calls the <xref:System.Web.Security.FormsAuthentication.SignOut%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method and sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.IPageAdapter.PersistCookielessData*> property to <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
